head.title: Suit Could Delay World War II Memorial

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/Washington, D.C.

hedline.hl1: Suit Could Delay World War II Memorial

abstract.p: Opponents of proposed national World War II memorial planned for Washington, DC, sue charging officials involved in site selection violated federal laws by 'encroaching' on Lincoln Memorial and not allowing public debate; seek to delay groundbreaking (S)

block.p: A suit filed in United States District Court here could delay the groundbreaking ceremony of the proposed national World War II memorial, plaintiffs in the case said today.

In the complaint, opponents of the memorial, which would be placed around the Mall's Rainbow Pool, say officials involved in the site's selection process violated federal laws. The plaintiffs say the proposed site violates one law by ''encroaching'' on the Lincoln Memorial.
A suit filed in United States District Court here could delay the groundbreaking ceremony of the proposed national World War II memorial, plaintiffs in the case said today.

In the complaint, opponents of the memorial, which would be placed around the Mall's Rainbow Pool, say officials involved in the site's selection process violated federal laws. The plaintiffs say the proposed site violates one law by ''encroaching'' on the Lincoln Memorial.
The plaintiffs also said the suit's defendants, including Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and Robert Stanton, director of the National Park Service, did not allow public debate.

Steve Thomas, a spokesman for the American Legion, a major donor to the project, said opponents did not consider the sacrifices of World War II veterans before filing the suit. The group is still hopeful that the planned groundbreaking ceremony will take place as scheduled on Veterans Day.
